Portland Electric

website redesign
Mobile prototype Website prototype

Project Overview

Company
Portland Electric is an electric company in Vancouver, WA. They have been on the market for more than 15 years, and never since did they update their website. Portland Electric has done a lot of big projects, and they mostly worked with the same clients for years, so they didn't need a good-functioned website a lot.

Task
Client needs a redesign of current website, adding additional features to it, make the site more user-centered and friendly.

Design goals
1. Redesign the existing website, to make it aesthetically pleasing, easy to navigate, and have all structure and content that the client provides (About page/ Contact page / Project page/ Services page)
2. Add the appointment form
3. Design a new, fresh logo for the company

Through the research and discovery phase, I find out that not all the users were ready to schedule estimate right away, some just wanted to contact and get more information, so we agreed on adding a contact form also.

Current Portland Electric website

Year
2020.

Duration
3 weeks

Tools
Figma
Maze

Discovery and research

User surveys
For this user survey, my main goal was to find out who is a target audience of PE site, which device they use when searching for the website, and also to get some feedback on what do they think about a current website, what information might be missing and what was their overall experience with PE website.

Survey participants habits:

45% - use a mobile device to search for a website

55% - use labtop

Information that participants looking the most when visiting PE website:

50% - services and definition

20% - reviews

15% - recent projects

Most of the participants:

70% - builders/ construction company manager or director

15,8% - interior designer

14,2% - other

Competitive analysis
According to survey results most users use the mobile app to plan their trip.
To determine the strengths and weaknesses of competitors I have done a competitive
analysis using SWOT method for the Moovit and Transit apps.

User persona
I created a user persona that includes two different user types: student Chandler and Monica.
What are their frustrations? What features do they find essential when using the app?
Personas helped me to represent a target user groups of my app and keep my design decisions user-centered.

Information architecture

User stories
User stories will give a more realistic understanding of the user's goals.
I created some for returning and new users and classified them by priority.

User flow
In order to see how user is going to accomplish a specific task user flow
was created. I focused on 3 user stories:

Wireframes
After conducting user research, finding out the personas, and creating user flow and
site map I finally got enough information for the next step of creating wireframes.
Using User stories and User flow, I began designing simple sketches at first.

Branding

Creating a design system
I wanted to go with a simple design, clear colors, and not overhelped it with
unnecessary items that will distract my users. My font for the entire app is Avenir,
which I think works perfectly for the transportation app, it's also pretty easy for people
to read and interact with.

Final product

Usability test and outcomes
This project scope required to do the usability testing after creating the Hifi prototype.
Usability tests were done via zoom, using HiFi prototype for the app. I had five
participants do three simple tasks, that helped to see how easy to navigate through the
app and how fast users will find information.

Through user testing, I found out that my app required two changes to make - add a
button to help navigate the user to the Full list of arrivals and add Back button on the
top menu bar.
 After applying those changes the process of using the app is more intuitive and users
find the right pages quickly. To find how far as the nearest station and when is the next
bus arriving user just needs 2 clicks.

Testing accessibility
The accessibility test was done using a Color contrast tracker. All pages meet the requirements.

Final product
On Time app needs to respond to the questions:
When is the next bus?
How much time does user need to get to the bus stop?

Solution
Problem solved with 2 clicks.
The app is easy to use.
The app is simply designed with the user's needs in mind.

See app in action
